private_information: Specializes in extracting STRIPS-style operator schemas and predicate vocabularies from textual rules.
Ensures parameters and predicate arities match the described actions without inventing new symbols.
domain_engineer.goal: Derive a precise, structured action model (predicates, actions, preconditions, add and delete effects) from the public rules.

private_information: Specializes in translating natural language initial states, objects, and goals into grounded planning instances.
Ensures all objects referenced in facts and goals are declared and that facts use only the known predicate vocabulary.
problem_engineer.goal: Provide consistent object sets and grounded initial states and goals for two scenarios, and capture any provided reference plans.

private_information: Checks candidate plans against the action model using classical STRIPS semantics (set add/delete effects, conjunctive preconditions).
Reports the first violating step and the missing preconditions or conflicts if the plan fails.
validator.goal: Validate the provided plan for scenario A against the extracted action model and instance, and summarize any issues or confirmations.

orchestrator.goal: Coordinate inputs from all agents and produce the final PDDL domain and problem instances targeting the Fast Downward solver.

public_information: Available objects: object_0, object_1, object_2, object_3, object_4, object_5, object_6, object_7, object_8, object_9, object_10, object_11, object_12.
Predicate vocabulary: hand(x), cats(x), texture(x), sneeze(x), spring(x), stupendous(x), collect(x,y), vase(x,y), next(x,y).
Action paltry a b c requires: hand a, cats b, texture c, vase a b, next b c; adds: next a c; deletes: vase a b.
Action sip a b c requires: hand a, cats b, texture c, next a c, next b c; adds: vase a b; deletes: next a c.
Action clip a b c requires: hand a, sneeze b, texture c, next b c, next a c; adds: vase a b; deletes: next a c.
Action wretched a b c d requires: sneeze a, texture b, texture c, stupendous d, next a b, collect b d, collect c d; adds: next a c; deletes: next a b.
Action memory a b c requires: cats a, spring b, spring c, next a b; adds: next a c; deletes: next a b.
Action tightfisted a b c requires: hand a, sneeze b, texture c, next b c, vase a b; adds: next a c; deletes: vase a b.

Scenario A initial facts: cats object_0; collect object_10 object_2; collect object_5 object_1; collect object_6 object_1; collect object_7 object_1; collect object_8 object_2; collect object_9 object_2; hand object_11; hand object_12; next object_0 object_5; next object_11 object_9; next object_12 object_10; next object_3 object_6; next object_4 object_8; sneeze object_3; sneeze object_4; spring object_5; spring object_8; stupendous object_1; stupendous object_2; texture object_10; texture object_5; texture object_6; texture object_7; texture object_8; texture object_9.
Scenario A goal: next object_11 object_7 and next object_12 object_5.

Scenario A provided plan (sequence): wretched object_3 object_6 object_5 object_1; wretched object_4 object_8 object_10 object_2; clip object_12 object_4 object_10; wretched object_4 object_10 object_9 object_2; clip object_11 object_4 object_9; wretched object_4 object_9 object_8 object_2; tightfisted object_12 object_4 object_8; tightfisted object_11 object_4 object_8; memory object_0 object_5 object_8; sip object_12 object_0 object_8; sip object_11 object_0 object_8; memory object_0 object_8 object_5; paltry object_12 object_0 object_5; paltry object_11 object_0 object_5; clip object_11 object_3 object_5; wretched object_3 object_5 object_7 object_1; tightfisted object_11 object_3 object_7.

Scenario B initial facts: cats object_0; collect object_10 object_2; collect object_5 object_1; collect object_6 object_1; collect object_7 object_1; collect object_8 object_2; collect object_9 object_2; hand object_11; hand object_12; next object_0 object_8; next object_11 object_6; next object_12 object_10; next object_3 object_7; next object_4 object_10; sneeze object_3; sneeze object_4; spring object_5; spring object_8; stupendous object_1; stupendous object_2; texture object_10; texture object_5; texture object_6; texture object_7; texture object_8; texture object_9.
Scenario B goal: next object_11 object_7 and next object_12 object_8.

model.system_prompt: You extract STRIPS-style operator schemas and predicate vocabularies from text. Output a concise JSON object with keys predicates and actions. Each action entry must include name, parameters (e.g., [a,b,c,d]), preconditions, add_effects, del_effects. Do not emit PDDL.
model.prompt: Your task is to read the public information and return a structured action model that exactly mirrors the described actions paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, and tightfisted using only the listed predicates. Keep symbol names identical to the text. Source: {environment->public_information}.

instances.system_prompt: You convert textual scenario descriptions into grounded planning instances. Output a JSON object with keys objects, scenario_a, scenario_b. Each scenario contains initial_facts, goals, and provided_plan if any. Do not emit PDDL.
instances.prompt: From the public information, enumerate all objects and build two grounded instances: scenario_a and scenario_b. For each, collect initial_facts and goals exactly as written and include the provided plan for scenario A as a list of action strings; for scenario B set provided_plan to null. Use only the given predicates and objects. Source: {environment->public_information}.

assess.system_prompt: You validate a plan using classical STRIPS semantics. Output a JSON object with keys scenario, is_valid, first_failure_step (index or null), reason (string), and notes (array). Do not emit PDDL.
assess.prompt: Validate the provided plan for scenario A by simulating preconditions and add/delete effects from the action model over the initial state. If a step violates preconditions, report the index and missing facts; otherwise confirm validity. Inputs: {action_model} and {problem_instances}.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in compiling multi-source planning specifications into PDDL for the Fast Downward solver. Produce one PDDL domain and two PDDL problem instances (scenario_a and scenario_b). The domain must use classical STRIPS features compatible with Fast Downward (:strips, no durative actions). Use the exact predicate and action names and signatures provided by the action model. Each problem must declare all objects, list initial facts, and a conjunctive goal. Always enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags, and each PDDL problem between <problem name="..."></problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: Integrate the extracted action model and grounded instances to produce the final PDDL. Resolve only symbol alignment issues if any and preserve the original names (predicates, actions, objects). Include both scenario_a and scenario_b as separate problem blocks compatible with Fast Downward. Inputs: action model: {action_model}; instances: {problem_instances}; validation: {plan_assessment}.
